thread.title: What happens now with Brexit? Theresa May's next move after no confidence vote

author: Sean Seddon
title: What happens now with Brexit? Theresa May's next move after no confidence vote
text:
News What happens now with Brexit? Theresa May's next move after no confidence vote Prime Minister Theresa May has survived a vote of no confidence triggered by her own backbenchers - so what happens now with the Government's Brexit policy Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Get daily updates directly to your inbox Subscribe Thank you for subscribing We have more newsletters Show me See our privacy notice Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email
Theresa May lives to fight another day.
The Prime Minister has come through the latest challenge put in front of her but the road ahead looks even trickier.
Conservative MPs rejected an attempt to oust her with a vote of no confidence in Westminster on Wednesday night after a dramatic 13 hours of uncertainty.
But she did not win the unanimous backing of her MPs: 200 voted in favour of Mrs May's continued leadership but 117 said they had no confidence in her.
Her less-than emphatic victory came at a price too.
The Prime Minister had to promise MPs she would resign before the next election, meaning a Tory leadership election could be on the cards as early as next year.
So what happens to the Government's Brexit policy now? Has anything changed? Will the EU be listening?
Here are all the scenarios, as reported by Mirror Online . What does Mrs May do now?
Having survived her confidence vote, the PM gets back on the plane to Brussels on Thursday morning where anxious EU leaders are gathering for their monthly summit.
Mrs May will get a chance to update the her counterparts who can then ask her questions. Read More
They will then go into private session, without Mrs May, to discuss Brexit before European Council president Donald Tusk and European Commission president Jean-Claude Juncker hold a press conference around 6pm [UK time].
With the clock ticking, Brussels is also expected to step up its own no deal preparations. What is her gameplan?
The PM is desparately seeking help from the EU to win over mutinuous Tory MPs in support of her deal.
More than 100 have spoken out publicly against it, in addition to the Democratic Unionist Party which props up the fragile Tory government.
Her only realistic chance of getting her withdrawal agreement through parliament is to persuade sceptical Tory and DUP Brexiteers the UK will not be trapped in the Irish border backstop indefinitely.
Brexiteer ministers have insisted that any change has to be legally binding. Read More How will she try to tweak her Brexit deal?
Downing Street has several ideas under discussion.
One is to ask Brussels for a letter of intent on the political declaration, which Tory sources have suggested could include the EU defining “temporary” as lasting for as little as three years.
Mrs May’s officials are also hoping to agree a clearer route out of the backstop through a legal “codicil” to the withdrawal agreement.
Mrs May wants to offer MPs - and possibly the European Parliament - an annual vote on whether to remain in the backstop if it is ever triggered. Will she get what she wants?
Unlikely.
Tusk says he is keen to help “facilitate UK ratification” and providing warm words shouldn’t be a problem for the EU.
But she will come up against a brick wall if she proposes any legal alterations to the substance of the withdrawal agreement. Read More Money Saving Expert Martin Lewis on how Brexit could impact house prices and mortgage rates
Juncker told her this week there was “no room whatsoever” to renegotiate the backstop, while German Chancellor Angela Merkel said there was “no way” to change the deal.
Brussels will not accept anything which prevents the backstop to avoid a hard border from coming into effect. But will her plans be enough to buy off her Tory rebels?
Probably not.
They have already dismissed the idea of a letter from the EU as a “figleaf” and have demanded legally binding assurances, which the EU has refused to give.
In the unlikely event Mrs May persuades Brussels to agree to give the UK a unilateral exit from the backstop - backbenchers would only support it if attorney general Geoffrey Cox made a statement guaranteeing it was legally binding.
Even if the PM resorts to threatening no deal to get what she wants, Tory Brexiteers think that EU diplomats wouldn't believe she would follow through. When will the meaningful take place?
Downing Street has confirmed that the postponed vote on Mrs May’s Brexit deal will take place before January 21st, even though technically she has until the eve of Brexit on March 29th.
But No 10 said Mrs May would “keep the spirit” of the EU withdrawal act and make statement on how she intended to proceed in the event of Brexit talks breaking down.
Although the vote could still take place before Christmas, Tory insiders have indicated early January is more likely as they hope the holiday will take the heat out of the rebellion What other options are on the table?
In a word: everything.
Jeremy Corbyn has said it was a matter of “when, not if” Labour tables a no confidence motion against the government in the House of Commons.
Much depends on the DUP, with rumours swirling they might vote against the government at first and back it in the second vote 14 days later, on the condition Theresa May steps down and a new Tory leader is ushered in. Read More 'I'm fed up with the Brexit negativity and the European religion!' Wetherspoons boss speaks in Newcastle pub
But it is improbable that a Brexiteer Tory leader would get the Commons behind them.
If Labour then failed to form a government, a general election would follow 21 days later under the Fixed Term Parliament Act. What about a second referendum? Anti-Brexit campaigners take part in the People's Vote March for the Future in London, a march and rally in support of a second EU referendum. (Image: PA)
Mrs May has ruled out going back to the people, saying it is too divisive.
Downing Street doesn’t want a referendum, nor is it planning for one.
But senior Number 10 sources believe this is where the country could end up.
It is also Labour’s second choice option, and senior figures have insisted that it could only ever be an absolute last resort.
But the longer that parliament remains deadlocked on Brexit , the more likely it is to happen. Like us on Facebook
